item.title: Minns says protesters 'almost troll-like', unleashing 'forces they can't control'
item.description: NSW Premier Chris Minns appeared to link the behaviour of some protesters to 'extreme actions' in the community.

item.title: Capped numbers, shorter licences: How gun laws are set to change in NSW
item.description: NSW parliament has passed new firearms legislation in the wake of the Bondi Beach terror attack.

item.title: Albanese government names groups it wants to crack down on amid anti-hate speech push
item.description: The Albanese government has revealed two groups in its sights for allegedly promoting hate and disunity.

item.description: A daily 5-minute news wrap for English learners and people with disability.

item.title: ASX hits six week high as gold reaches another record
item.description: SBS Finance Editor Ricardo Gonçalves speaks with Jamie Hannah from VanEck to find out what's driving the market as the Santa Rally continues.

item.title: Turning points: what defined the world in 2025
item.description: 2025 has been a huge year for geopolitics, natural disasters and a changing of the guard at the top levers of international power and influence. We look back at the key moments.

item.title: Israeli president's planned post-Bondi-attack visit to Australia draws mixed reaction
item.description: While mainstream Jewish organisations have welcomed Isaac Herzog's recently announced visit to Australia, others have expressed dismay.

item.title: How one phone call cost Vicky $47,000
item.description: With Australia introducing world-first scam prevention legislation earlier this year, we hear from people who are seeking justice.

item.title: Not all sunglasses protect you from eye damage. Here's how to spot the difference
item.description: Some sunglasses can put you at risk of eye damage. Here's how to tell the difference.

item.title: UK national facing deportation for alleged display of Nazi symbols, Burke confirms
item.description: The news comes after a South African man had his visa cancelled in November for taking part in a neo-Nazi rally.

item.title: SBS News In Easy English 24 December 2025
item.description: A daily news bulletin for English learners and people with a disability.

item.title: US economy expands more than expected as local ASX Santa rally hits snag
item.description: SBS Finance Editor Ricardo Gonçalves speaks with Mathan Somasundram from Deep Data Analytics about the better than expected US GDP result and what it means for interest rates, plus a look ahead to 2026 on the markets.

item.title: 'Impossibly high threshold': Northern Territory bail laws facing High Court challenge
item.description: An Aboriginal legal service in the NT will launch a challenge to laws it says undermine fundamental legal principles.

item.title: Desi carols, card games and carp: Some Christmas customs you might've never heard about
item.description: Around the world, and in migrant communities across Australia, a diverse range of customs give Christmas a unique flavour.

item.title: A heroine, a monster and true love - the new genre that's overturned the book world
item.description: It's not science fiction, but it has elements. It's not romance, but it touches the heart. It's not fantasy but don't be surprised if you encounter a werewolf or an elf. It's the new literary craze which is taking the book world by storm, driven by millions of fans on the social media platform TikTok. It's called romantasy.

item.title: The full beauty of Lake St Clair's depths is revealed
item.description: Lake St Clair is surrounded by Tasmania's Wilderness World Heritage area and was carved out by glaciers over millions of years. It's around twice as deep as Bass Strait, but Australia's deepest lake has never been fully mapped. Until now: CSIRO scientists have produced the first 3D map of the underwater landscape, confirming the vast depth of the natural wonder.

item.title: NSW Police invoke new powers to restrict Sydney protests for two weeks
item.description: NSW Police have imposed temporary limits on public gatherings under emergency laws passed in response to the Bondi terror attack.

item.title: How to safely store your Christmas leftovers and avoid food poisoning
item.description: If your Christmas feast has finished and you see large portions of food untouched on your table, you might only have a couple of hours to keep them.

item.title: Ready for take-off? Here's how international travel is changing in 2026
item.description: From fresh international routes to new digital identity requirements, here's what you need to know about heading overseas next year.

item.title: Burnt out from 2025? Here's how to actually rest over the break
item.description: December can be a stressful time of year, and not everyone returns to work refreshed after the festive season.

item.title: Pope Leo decries conditions for Palestinians in Gaza in first Christmas sermon
item.description: In an address from the balcony of St Peter's Basilica, the pontiff also called for an end to conflicts in Ukraine, Sudan, Thailand and Cambodia.

item.title: Victoria Police name person of interest in Hanukkah car fire
item.description: Victoria Police is searching for a person of interest as part of its early investigation into a suspected arson attack in south-east Melbourne.

item.title: The hidden workforce behind Melbourne’s tram seats
item.description: Melbourne’s trams have been part of the city for more than 140 years. Almost half a million people ride them each day — but few know the story behind the seats they sit on.

item.title: Why the US struck IS targets in Nigeria, and why an expert says Trump is 'oversimplifying' it
item.description: Announcing the strikes, Trump claimed terrorists had been targeting Christians "at levels not seen for many years" in Nigeria.

item.title: Boxing Day sales: How to get the best bang for your buck — and the scams to watch out for
item.description: Australians are expected to spend more on Boxing Day sales this year. Here's how to take

item.title: Refugee hotline sees spike in calls for help after Bondi terror attack
item.description: A hotline supporting refugees who have fled war, violence and persecution has received a funding boost after the Bondi terror attack. Those running the hotline service in New South Wales says the funding will allow it to extend its reach nationally, supporting refugees as they navigate the ongoing effects of complex trauma and triggers of what happened at Bondi.

item.title: SBS News In Easy English 26 December 2025
item.description: A daily news bulletin for English learners and people with a disability.

item.title: Have an hour to spare these holidays? It could make a big difference to your retirement
item.description: Many Australians don’t know their super balance or how it’s invested — and the super industry says the holidays are a good time to change that.

item.title: Another election, 'no winner'? What’s at stake in Kosovo's snap vote
item.description: The Balkan country is headed to the polls on Sunday, after nearly a year of political deadlock that's caused "colossal damage" to its economy.

item.title: From the White House to the Vatican: A year of global turning points
item.description: Here's a look at 2025, shaped by global events — from political shifts to natural disasters — defining a year of change and challenge.

item.title: As the housing crisis worsens, this city hotel is helping to build homes for at-risk women
item.description: .Raising funds to ease homelessness among women is the focus of a Sydney hotel, one of 12,000 social enterprises in Australia that combine profit with purpose.

item.title: New developments and old battles: Australia's health year in 2025
item.description: As with most years, the health sector has been a constant source of news stories - from outbreaks of illnesses to outstanding medical research, from politics to pandemics, from injuries to infections. SBS news looks back at some of the medical stories that hit the news in 2025.

item.title: Two dead in alleged Palestinian ramming and knife attack in Israel
item.description: It comes a day after an Israeli reservist allegedly rammed his vehicle into a Palestinian man as he prayed on a roadside in the occupied West Bank.

item.title: Elusive wild cat thought to be extinct rediscovered in Thailand after 30 years
item.description: Flat-headed cats are among the world's rarest and most threatened wild felines, with the last documented sighting in Thailand in 1995.

item.title: 'We have to do more': Wong apologises to Jewish community over Bondi terror attack
item.description: The foreign minister said she would visit Bondi at an appropriate time, also conceding more had to be done to combat antisemitism.

item.title: How a hostel set up over 100 years ago is still helping to change women's lives
item.description: A century-old women's hostel has evolved, but it's continued its mission of supporting housing for women.

item.title: How changing our safety signs could save lives every summer
item.description: Experts are warning that Australia's beach warning signs do not clearly convey the message to those who do not speak English as a first language.

item.title: Thailand and Cambodia announce 'immediate' ceasefire
item.description: The ceasefire follows three days of border negotiations, announced after a crisis meeting of ASEAN foreign ministers.

item.title: 'Guerrilla rewilding': The people controversially fighting to restore near-extinct animals
item.description: Rewilders around the world have sought to reintroduce species to their traditional habitats. But not all efforts have official approval.

item.title: Inside Australia's rental crunch — and what the numbers say about 2026
item.description: As summer listings rise, a tight supply and strong demand keep affordability pressures high. Here's what's next for the rental market in 2026.

item.title: What are Australians reading? The book genres Australians are loving the most
item.description: As the holiday season hits there's nothing like grabbing a good book, heading to a cool shady spot and reading a story that takes you into another world. But with so many digital distractions, how popular are books and what genres are catching readers' interest the most? Please note: This story contains sexual references.

item.title: How young birdwatchers are taking flight in the digital age
item.description: .When you think of birdwatching, retirees probably come to mind. But a new generation is picking up binoculars and taking on the hobby. What was once an escape from the online world is making a comeback online.

item.title: Cyclone Alfred among top ten costliest climate-change-linked disasters of 2025
item.description: Economic losses caused by the fierce storm that ravaged southeast Queensland and northern NSW clocked in at roughly $1.8 billion.

item.title: Minns vows to keep 'racist' preacher's venue shut, flags new security plans
item.description: The premier flagged the possibility of deploying the army to protect Jewish institutions and arming a Jewish community security organisation.

item.title: Got some spare cash in the bank? Here's what experts say you should do with it
item.description: It's important to factor in your age, income and financial goals when making an investment plan.

item.title: 'Envy of the developed world': Is our superannuation system working for all Australians?
item.description: Australians collectively have more than $4 trillion in superannuation. However, some question whether the system is truly benefiting them.

item.title: French film icon Brigitte Bardot dies aged 91
item.description: Brigitte Bardot was propelled into international stardom when she played a teen bride in the 1956 movie And God Created Woman.

item.title: 'It's patronising': Ley criticises PM as he resists fresh calls for Bondi royal commission
item.description: There have been growing calls for a federal inquiry into antisemitism, but Anthony Albanese has so far declined to pursue one.

item.title: Low voter turnout in first Myanmar elections since 2021 military coup
item.description: The military junta said the election would bring political stability to Myanmar, despite rights groups saying the vote was neither free nor fair.

item.description: Belonging nowhere is a reality for millions of people around the world: it's known as statelessness. Described by some as an overlooked human rights issue, this first episode delves into the history of statelessness and who stateless people are.

item.description: Proposed reforms would expand whistleblower protections, but advocates say they don't go far enough.

item.title: Tim hopes a treechange will help him save a house deposit. He's not alone
item.description: Young Australians are moving to remote or regional Australia to fast-track their savings. But is it worth the sacrifice?

item.description: Australia enters 2026 with an unchanged migration cap, tighter skilled priorities, more student places and reforms triggered by the Bondi attack, but experts say issues remain.

item.description: Trump said he still believed Iran was still interested in a deal with the US on its nuclear and missile programs.

item.description: A man in his 70s was found dead in a submerged vehicle in north-west Queensland on Tuesday afternoon.

item.title: REPLAY: Belonging Nowhere: How hard is it to feel like you belong in Australia?
item.description: Many stateless people are displaced around the world, attempting to find somewhere they can call home. Their journeys can often take a heavy toll, as they deal with traumatic experiences, or need to hid their true identities as a persecuted minority. In this second episode of 'Belonging Nowhere' we’ll hear some of the many stories of how people from different stateless backgrounds come to Australia – and the difficulties they’ve faced trying to make a home.

item.title: Two killed in boxer Anthony Joshua crash identified as 'close friends and team members'
item.description: The two fatalities were identified as Joshua's close friends.

item.title: Bangladesh's first female prime minister Khaleda Zia dies at 80
item.description: Khaleda Zia was seen as a frontrunner to win the February 2026 general election in Bangladesh.

item.description: From true crime to the rise of 'single dad' fiction — these are the reads Australians couldn't get enough of in 2025.

item.description: The military exercises are believed to be some of Beijing's largest to date.

item.description: In their New Year's addresses, the prime minister and Opposition leader delivered a strong message of hope, courage and unity.

item.description: We hear from Australian men who are figuring out what it means to be a man in an evolving contemporary context.

item.description: From tax cuts to payday super, a number of changes are coming for Australians across childcare, household budgets and medicines.

item.description: Israel says it will suspend several humanitarian organisations for failing to meet its new rules to vet international organisations working in Gaza.

item.title: Why are students and shopkeepers demonstrating across Iran?
item.description: Iran's economy, already battered by decades of sanctions, was further strained after the UN in late September reinstated international sanctions.

item.title: Why predicting bushfires this summer has been 'particularly tricky'
item.description: A weaker La Niña and an unusual warming high above Antarctica are pulling Australia's weather in opposite directions, experts say.

item.title: Why this Australian K-pop star is being sued for $44 million in South Korea
item.description: The company behind hit K-pop group NewJeans has filed a lawsuit against one of the group's members, marking the latest development in a long-running dispute.

item.title: Russia deploys nuclear-capable missiles to Belarus
item.description: Russia says nuclear-capable missiles have been deployed to Belarus and are in active service. It brings the weapons closer to Europe as Russia toughens its negotiating position in peace talks with Ukraine.

item.title: The year that was on the ASX and the year ahead
item.description: SBS Finance Editor Ricardo Gonçalves speaks with Mark Gardner from MPC Markets about whether investors should be happy with the near 7% return on the ASX200 this year and what the key investment themes for 2026 will likely be.

item.title: In pictures and videos: These were the moments that defined 2025
item.description: A look back at the images and moments that defined Australia and the world in 2025.

item.title: Aid agencies in Gaza condemn Israel's suspension of their licences to operate
item.description: The Israeli government is set to revoke the licences of 37 aid groups working in Gaza and the West Bank, which have failed to meet its new vetting rules. Israel says the suspensions will not affect the delivery of aid, but the move has drawn widespread criticism.

item.title: China responds to Australian criticism of military drills, Taiwan still on high alert
item.description: Australia said on Wednesday that China's military drills around Taiwan were "deeply concerning, destabilising and risk inflaming regional tensions".

item.description: Philip Ruddock, the father of Australia's controversial asylum seekers policy, says the Opposition shouldn't fixate on numbers.

item.description: Declassified documents reveal what John Howard's cabinet considered, and ignored, when sending troops to Afghanistan.

item.title: Australians ring in 2026 with a focus on peace and unity
item.description: New Year's Eve revellers have had a moment of silent reflection for the Bondi victims before enjoying brilliant firework displays across the county.

item.title: Australians celebrate the start of 2026 | Morning Bulletin 1 January 2026
item.description: Australians celebrate the start of 2026, Racist flyers found in letterboxes in Newcastle, Team Canada and China's tennis stars visit a Sydney zoo ahead of their United Cup campaign.

item.title: Disasters, defence and pandemics: what the cabinet papers reveal about 2005
item.description: Hundreds of newly released cabinet papers reveal the inner workings of the Howard government in the mid-noughties with warnings about the role that defence personnel should play in Afghanistan and Australia's preparedness for a pandemic.

item.title: Should artificial intelligence be used in job recruitment?
item.description: The use of AI in recruitment is on the rise, with almost two thirds of Australian organisations believed to be using the technology in their job hiring processes. There are growing concerns over the risks of discrimination.

item.title: Trump says national guard troops being pulled from Chicago, LA and Portland
item.description: Trump said in a social media post that federal forces will "come back" if crime rates go up.

item.title: Israeli military kills man in West Bank, UN condemns utilities cut to Palestinian refugee agency
item.description: The Israeli military killed a man in the occupied West Bank on Thursday. Separately, the UN has criticised Israel's ban on supplying water or electricity to UNRWA facilities.

item.title: 'Weak agreements only fuel the war': Zelenskyy says Ukraine ready for a 'strong peace'
item.description: "Are we tired? Very. Does ‍this mean we are ready to surrender? Anyone who thinks so is deeply mistaken," Zelenskyy said in his New Year address.

item.title: Albanese rejects human rights commissioner's call for Bondi royal commission
item.description: The prime minister has continued to resist calls for a royal commission into the Bondi attack after a new voice joined the chorus appealing for one.

item.title: Government 'disappointed' with China's new beef import tariffs
item.description: An industry group has also warned the newly announced tariffs could damage trade worth over $1 billion between Australia and China.

item.title: Australian man reportedly killed while fighting in Ukraine
item.description: The Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade said it was seeking to confirm the reported death with authorities in Ukraine.

item.title: Dakar Rally 2026 nears as Aussie champ Daniel Sanders eyes 'back-to-back' wins
item.description: The 48th edition of the Dakar Rally kicks off this weekend in Saudi Arabia. Here's what to know about the gruelling motor race.

item.title: Power, pirate flags and political upheaval: How youth-led protests spread across borders
item.description: From Kathmandu to Manila, 2025 became a year when streets pushed back. Youth-led protests challenged corruption, demanding accountability.

item.title: Sparklers pinpointed as cause of Swiss New Year's blaze that killed 40 and injured over 100
item.description: Investigators say sparklers held under a foam-clad ceiling likely ignited the deadly blaze.

item.title: Trump says US will intervene if Iran 'violently kills' protesters after reports of six deaths
item.description: Protests in Iran that started over high rates of inflation and a fall in the currency have led to several deaths, Iranian media reports say.

item.title: REPLAY: Belonging nowhere: Stateless in Australia
item.description: While statelessness affects millions of people around the world, Australia also has stateless people.The United Nations refugee agency says there are around 8,000 stateless people in Australia, but experts say there could be more. The UNHCR is calling on the Australian government to create a stateless determination procedure (SDP), which would contribute to efforts to assess the size and the situation of stateless population amongst migrant populations.The fourth episode of Belonging Nowhere looks at Australia and how it deals with statelessness.

item.title: 'I put myself out there': Khawaja calls stumps on international career with message to critics
item.description: Khawaja said he'll forever carry the memories, friendships and "lessons that shaped me".

item.title: Crowd chants 'tax the rich' as Zohran Mamdani sworn in as first Muslim mayor of New York
item.description: Mamdani, a self-described democratic socialist, comes to power at a time when Trump has pushed a hard-right agenda.

item.title: Resort fire on NY Eve one of Switzerland's deadliest disasters
item.description: A New Year’s Eve celebration at a luxury Alpine ski resort has ended in one of the deadliest disasters in Switzerland's modern history. Around 40 people are dead and more than 100 injured, including one Australian, after a fire tore through a crowded nightclub in the early hours of New Year’s Day, triggering scenes of panic, chaos and devastation. A warning: this story has elements that may distress some people.

item.description: A five minute bulletin for English language learners

item.description: From advocating for representation to speaking out on Gaza, Usman Khawaja's influence reaches well beyond the boundary — with many Australians viewing him as "a symbol of resilience and inclusion".

item.title: China reimposes taxes on condoms, contraceptive drugs to spur flagging birth rate
item.description: China's population fell for a third consecutive year in 2024 and experts have warned the downturn will continue.

item.title: Searches called off for missing swimmers after 'absolutely horrendous' start to 2026
item.description: The scaling-back of search efforts follows a series of fatal drownings described by the Surf Life Saving NSW CEO as an "absolutely horrendous" start to the year.

item.title: China's New Year surprise: hefty new tariff on beef exports exceeding quota
item.description: Australia’s billion-dollar beef trade faces a massive shakeup as China imposes a new 55 per cent tariff on imports that exceed strictly capped annual quotas. While the Chinese government claims the move will protect its farmers from oversupply, Australian industry leaders and the Federal Opposition warn the tariff increase breaches the spirit of Australia's long-standing free trade agreement with China.

item.title: The opposition leader in exile who once ran against Europe's longest-reigning autocrat
item.description: Meet the woman sentenced to 15 years in prison in her home country who Australian leaders call "a fearless advocate for democracy and justice".

item.title: As calls grow for a Bondi royal commission, do Albanese's arguments stand up?
item.description: The prime minister has said an intelligence review is a faster and more appropriate tool to get answers on the Bondi terror attack.

item.title: Vietnam's battlefields drawing tourists, 50 years on from war
item.description: Some remember the Vietnam War battles from the headlines of the 1960s and 1970s, and some from movies and history books. Others know them as the graveyards of loved ones who died fighting more than a half-century ago. Today, the battlefields of Vietnam are sites of pilgrimage for veterans from both sides who fought there, and tourists wanting to see firsthand where the war was waged.

item.title: 'Alarming' spike in magpies paralysed by mystery illness
item.description: While many options have been ruled out, one expert says researchers are not any closer to identifying the cause of the illness.

item.description: As many Aussies tighten their purse strings, here's what budget-conscious travellers can expect before hitting these predicted travel hotspots.

item.description: If you miss tonight's supermoon, you'll need to wait for months to see the next one.

item.description: Venezuelan President Nicolas Maduro and his wife have been 'captured and flown out of the country', US President Donald Trump has said.

item.description: Experts say AI won't just replace jobs — it could spark new industries and opportunities Australians can't yet imagine.

item.description: A new online learning module is aiming to provide education and support around intimacy rights for people with disability.

item.title: AI Art generates cash and controversy at the same time
item.description: Artificial intelligence is turning ideas into art. It’s being auctioned for thousands of dollars and increasingly winning art prizes. But visual artists are divided about what this new movement means for their job futures and the future of creativity.

item.title: Laura’s plant-based milk is changing the lives of some of the world’s poorest women
item.description: Australia’s non-dairy milk market is worth more than $600 million annually and is growing rapidly. One plant-based milk business run by an Australian entrepreneur also supports some of the world’s poorest women.

item.title: The questions still hanging over Trump's plan to 'run' Venezuela
item.description: Donald Trump is insisting the United States is in charge of Venezuela and has not ruled out putting "boots on the ground".

item.title: Australia awaits facts and clarity on US weekend military operation in Venezuela
item.description: As the world digests the US capture of Venezuela’s President Nicolás Maduro, the Australian government is calling for diplomatic restraint while domestic critics warn the military operation constitutes a "gross breach" of international law. The Coalition is backing what it calls the "decisive action" against a government they link to global drug trafficking, while the Greens and legal experts warn that failing to condemn the raid sets a dangerous precedent for global aggression and puts Australian sovereignty at risk.

item.title: Three-day childcare subsidy now in place - but will it help families?
item.description: Parents sending children to childcare are now guaranteed a 90 per cent subsidy for three days a week, without completing any eligibility test. The subsidy will cost around $430 million over the next four years but the government says hundreds of thousands of families are set to benefit.

item.title: Flooding in northwest Queensland hits three cattle stations
How the US operation to 'capture' Nicolás Maduro in Venezuela unfolded
item.description: Months before the lightning operation, the US army was preparing for the capture of Nicolás Maduro.

item.title: 'Absolutely terrified': How Judi's daunting travel moment reshaped her life
item.description: A mix of grief, fear and empowerment is driving more widowed women to travel alone. Experts say the shift speaks to how women navigate life after loss.

item.title: 'I don't want to go back': The Australians reinventing themselves in midlife
item.description: Most of us will reassess our purpose in midlife and many of us will completely switch careers — although it doesn't always work out.

item.title: 'I don't want to go back': The Australians reinventing themselves in midlife
item.description: Most of us will reassess our purpose in midlife and many of us will completely switch careers — although it doesn't always work out.

item.title: Nicolás Maduro pleads not guilty as he tells US court he is still Venezuela's president
item.description: The Venezuelan president and his wife Cilia Flores have told a court in New York they are innocent.

item.title: Venezuelan President Nicolas Maduro pleads not guilty in a U-S court | Morning News Bulletin 6 January 2026
item.description: Venezuelan President Nicolas Maduro and his wife plead not guilty to charges in a U-S court; China demands the U-S immediately release captured Venezuelan leader Nicolas Maduro; In tennis, local hope Alexei Popyrin defeated by France's Quentin Halys at the Brisbane International.

item.title: Paris court finds 10 people guilty of cyberbullying French first lady Brigitte Macron
item.description: The defendants were accused of posting "malicious comments" about Macron's gender and the age gap between her and Emmanuel Macron.

item.title: Alleged Bondi shooter moved to Goulburn supermax prison | Midday News Bulletin 6 January 2026
item.description: New South Wales's opposition unveils new Shadow Cabinet; Alleged Bondi shooter moved to Goulbourn supermax prison; And in tennis, Novak Djokovic withdraws from next week's Adelaide International.

item.title: The PM to visit flood-hit communities in north-west Qld after worst flooding in decades
Big names and a troubled past: The 'uniquely onerous' jail Nicolás Maduro is being held in
item.description: The ousted Venezuelan leader joins a slew of high-profile names who've been held at the notorious Brooklyn prison.

item.title: I'm a decent man: Maduro pleads not guilty to US charges
item.description: Former Venezuelan President Nicolás Maduro has pleaded not guilty to so-called narco-terrorism charges in New York's federal court. As criticism builds over the US assault in Venezuela, so too do fears over similar military operations elsewhere.

item.title: SBS News In Easy English 6 January 2026
item.description: A daily 5 minute news bulletin for English learners, and people with a disability.

item.title: Police investigate antisemitism link to man arrested over alleged arson attack in Melbourne
item.description: A 47-year-old man is in custody awaiting an interview with investigators.

item.title: 'One has to take it a bit more seriously': Greenland residents concerned by US actions in Venezuela
item.description: Denmark’s Prime Minister Mette Frederiksen believes Donald Trump is 'very serious' about wanting control of Greenland, a largely autonomous part of the Danish kingdom. President Trump has repeatedly said the US ‘must’ control it for national security reasons, sparking real concern among European leaders who have backed Denmark’s position.

item.title: Government announces $38 million for flood-affected Queenslanders | Evening News Bulletin 6 January 2026
item.description: The government announces $38 million in relief for flood affected-Queenslanders; Venezuelan parliament swears in Delcy Rodriguez as interim leader; And in cricket, the SCG is awash in pink for the 18th Pink Test fundraiser for in-home cancer nurses.

item.title: The US v Nicolás Maduro: Is the Venezuelan leader facing life in jail?
item.description: Nicolás Maduro could rely on a number of legal defences to avoid potential life imprisonment. But that path faces several hurdles.

item.title: Queensland farmers to receive millions in flood rescue package after 'significant' livestock losses
item.description: Some farmers are concerned about major financial losses, with about 16,500 cattle estimated to be dead or missing.

item.title: Is this already the biggest potential takeover of 2026 on the ASX?
item.description: SBS Finance Editor Ricardo Gonçalves speaks with Chris Brycki from Stockspot about the Dow Jones Index overnight record and takes a closer look at the joint takeover bid for Bluescope Steel.

item.title: Nearly seven million Australians at risk from urban fires, new report warns
item.description: Almost seven million people living on the expanding fringes of Australia's capital cities are at risk from urban fires similar to those seen in Los Angeles last year. The warning, by former Australian fire chiefs and the Climate Council comes as the country is set to swelter in one of the most significant heatwaves of recent years.

item.title: Protesters banned from Sydney streets for another two weeks under controversial restrictions
item.description: The controversial protest ban can be extended every fortnight for up to three months.

item.title: 'A big problem': Fresh questions about Maduro operation after closed-door briefing
item.description: While some Republicans have defended the military action, some Democrats have accused the administration of lying about its reasoning.

item.title: 'I shouldn't have done it': The parents who regret having kids
item.description: While the challenges of parenthood are intensifying, experts say regretting children is still an 'unsayable' reality.

item.title: The reality virtually no Aussie can escape when a heatwave hits
item.description: Everyone in heatwave-affected areas is at risk — even "healthy, fit young people". Here's how extreme heat affects your body and how to stay safe.

item.title: Military 'always an option', US says, after pushback against renewed Greenland threats
item.description: The US has struck a defiant tone after major European powers and Canada rallied behind Greenland on Tuesday.

item.title: Talks on Ukraine underway in Paris| Morning News Bulletin 7 January 2026
item.description: Talks on Ukraine are underway in Paris; New South Wales Police Commissioner extends post-Bondi protest restrictions; In tennis, the Australian Open prize fund increases to $111.5 million.

item.title: 'We bitterly regret this': Swiss authorities' admission about bar where 40 died in NYE fire
item.description: Regular fire safety inspections had not been carried out at the bar where a deadly fire broke out on New Year's Eve, authorities have said.

item.title: Zelenskyy praises European, US moves towards legally binding security guarantees for Ukraine
item.description: Discussions on security guarantees for Ukraine have advanced among Western allies, but Russia has given no public sign it would accept the arrangements.

item.title: Trump says Venezuelan oil to be shipped to US ports as 'war crime' attack condemned
item.description: The US president said the oil "will be taken by storage ships, and brought directly to unloading docks in the United States".

item.title: Donald Trump considers the use of the US military to acquire Greenland | Midday News Bulletin 7 January 2026
item.description: Donald Trump considers the use of the US military as a potential option to acquire Greenland; Australia set to experience the worst heatwave since the black summer bushfires; and in tennis, Australia advances to the United Cup quarter-finals.

item.title: US attacks in Venezuela violate UN Charter, says United Nations
item.description: The United Nations has condemned the US attacks in Venezuela over the weekend as a direct violation of the UN charter. As the former Venezuelan President Nicolás Maduro awaits his next court date in New York, the Venezuelan Attorney General joins others urging recognition of Mr Maduro's immunity under international law.

item.title: SBS News In Easy English 7 January 2026
item.description: A daily 5 minute news bulletin for English learners, and people with a disability.

item.title: Why the latest inflation dip 'keeps alive' interest rate hike expectations
item.description: Headline inflation has come in lower than expected. But will that mean an interest rate reprieve? Not necessarily, economists say.

item.title: Debate over hate speech reforms after Bondi terror attack | Evening News Bulletin 7 January 2026
item.description: Debate over hate speech reforms after the Bondi terror attack; inflation eases in Australia, but remains above the Reserve Bank's target; and Australian Daniel Sanders retains his lead in the Dakar Rally

item.title: Behind Trump's controversial push to acquire Greenland
item.description: Trump's attention is again on Greenland — but why? Here's what to know, as allies raise alarm and talks are set for next week.

item.title: What is diet stacking and are you doing it?
item.description: Fodmap, high protein, gluten-free, lowfat, clean eating - so many diets, so much conflicting advice. Australian experts are warning that following multiple diets at the same time could have unexpected consequences.

item.title: Australia's trees are dying faster than they're being replaced
item.description: A new study has found trees across Australia are dying at a faster rate than new ones are growing, a trend that is contributing to an increase in carbon emissions. The research, led by Western Sydney University and published in the Nature Plants journal, has found trees in all types of ecosystems - from tropical rainforests to eucalypt forests - are thinning as the climate warms.

item.title: Is easing inflation enough to stop a February interest rate rise?
item.description: SBS Finance Editor Ricardo Gonçalves speaks to Pradeep Philip, from Deloitte Access Economics, and Alice Shen, CFA from VanEck, about the latest inflation result and the day's sharemarket moves.

item.title: Pressure increases on PM to establish post-Bondi Royal Commission
item.description: Following the final funeral for a victim of the Bondi terror attack, the Coalition has ramped up pressure on the Government to launch a Royal Commission with a specific focus on government accountability and extremist ideology. While the Opposition has detailed a three-commissioner model, the Government remains cautious, with analysts suggesting concerns over how the inquiry's scope might affect social cohesion and the broader national agenda.

item.title: Structures lost in Victoria bushfire as Australians swelter through intense heatwave
item.description: Much of Australia is being gripped by a heatwave, which will bring "catastrophic" fire danger to Victoria on Friday.

item.title: How to slash your bills and get money back into your pocket quickly
item.description: If you want to get your year started on the right financial footing, here are 10 ways to save money.

item.title: I'm 50, I've failed, and I finally feel like myself
item.description: In her 40s, Sarah experienced divorce, alcoholism and job loss. Now in her 50s, she's reinventing herself.

item.title: The US says it's actively discussing buying Greenland | Morning News Bulletin 8 January 2026
item.description: Fire authorities warn Victoria set to endure extreme fire conditions amid an ongoing heatwave; The US says it's actively discussing buying Greenland; And in sport, Australia within sight of 4-1 Ashes series victory as the Sydney Test enters its final day.

item.title: US outlines plan to control Venezuelan oil 'indefinitely' as tankers seized in North Atlantic
item.description: US secretary of state Marco Rubio has outlined a three-fold process for Venezuela's future, focusing on stabilisation, recovery and transition.

item.title: Greenland says it will join talks with US and Denmark amid Trump acquisition push
item.description: Greenland has repeatedly stated it does not wish to be part of the US, which, under Donald Trump, has expressed interest in acquiring the Danish territory.

item.title: Woman fatally shot by ICE in Minneapolis identified, officials spar over cause of shooting
item.description: The US government said the agent fired in self-defence, while the local mayor said video of the incident contradicted that narrative.

item.title: 'Leave as soon as possible': Advice for Australians updated as deadly protests escalate
item.description: DFAT says a violent crackdown on protests in Iran has left many "injured, killed or detained", and is urging Australians to depart the country.

item.title: US immigration officer fatally shoots woman during deportation raid | Midday News Bulletin 8 January 2026
item.description: US immigration officer fatally shoots woman during mass deportation raid; The possibility of a total fire ban in Victoria, as conditions get hotter; And in sport, a change of coach doesn't bring an immediate reward for Manchester United.

item.title: Trump pulls out of UN climate agreement, 66 bodies deemed 'contrary' to US interests
item.description: The US will withdraw from the treaty underpinning all major international climate agreements and the UN climate science body, according to a White House memo.

item.title: SBS News In Easy English 8 January 2026
item.description: A daily 5 minute news bulletin for English learners and people with a disability.

item.title: US seizes two Venezuela-linked oil tankers
item.description: The United States has seized two oil tankers linked to Venezuela from the North Atlantic Ocean and the Caribbean Sea. The seizure takes place days after the US captured Venezuelan President Nicolas Maduro and his wife in a pre-dawn military operation. It's prompted renewed calls for the US to comply with international law and respect trade between sovereign nations.

item.title: How hot can it get? Australia's record-high temperatures — and where they were set
item.description: Here's a look at the country's most extreme temperature records.

item.title: Anthony Albanese expected to announce commonwealth royal commission | Evening News Bulletin 8 January 2026
item.description: Anthony Albanese expected to announce a commonwealth royal commission after weeks of pressure; Catastrophic fire danger warnings issued for Victoria tomorrow; And in cricket, Australia's 4-1 Ashes domination of England is complete with win in the fifth test.

item.title: Fighting in Aleppo sends thousands of Syrian civilians fleeing
item.description: Syria's government is demanding that Kurdish fighters leave the neighbourhoods they control in Aleppo following clashes between the two sides which saw thousands of civilians flee. The clashes in the north Syrian city have killed at least 16 civilians, prompting calls from the United Nations for a peaceful resolution to the conflict.

item.title: Albanese announces Bondi terror royal commission as Ley says he was 'forced' into it
item.description: The announcement has been welcomed by the antisemitism envoy, while a state-level royal commission in NSW will no longer go ahead.

item.title: The sharemarket up 100% in just 3 days & Bluescope rejects takeover bid
item.description: SBS Finance Editor Ricardo Gonçalves takes a look at why some global markets are hitting record levels with Matt Wacher from Morningstar, plus why BlueScope has rejected a $13bn takeover bid.

item.title: Trump's crude move on Venezuela, unrest in Iran & China's condom conundrum
item.description: President Maduro snatched from his bed, Trump’s grab for Greenland unifies Europe. Plus, nationwide protests rattle the Iranian regime, and China’s stiff rise in the cost of condoms.

item.title: Where will prices grow the most? This year's property market predictions
item.description: Some believe there could be a "levelling out" of the market.

item.title: Trump sending message to Putin, Venezuela and the world with tanker seizure, experts say
item.description: The US has seized a Russian-flagged oil tanker in the Atlantic, after tracking it for weeks and calling in the assistance of the UK.

item.title: Should Australia give names to heatwaves?
item.description: In Australia, the only severe weather events that receive formal names are tropical cyclones. Could there be benefits to naming all of our extreme weather?
